introduction.p: Horizontal transformations affect the x-coordinate of a graph, so they are accomplished by a change in the x-coordinate of the equation, before the function is applied.
Vertical transformations affect the y-coordinate of a graph, so they are accomplished by a change in the y-coordinate of the equation, after the function is applied.

statement.p:
Write a formula for the transformed function.
f(x)=\dfrac{1}{x},~~g(x)=f(x)-3
f(x)=\dfrac{1}{x^2},~~g(x+4)
f(x)=\sqrt[3]{x},~~g(x)=\dfrac{1}{3}f(x)
f(x)=|x|,~~g(x)=-f(x)

ol.label: a
ol.li: We subtract 3 from the formula for f(x): ~~g(x)=\dfrac{1}{x}-3
We add 4 to x before applying the function. Think of replacing x by x+4 wherever it appears in the formula for f(x): ~~g(x)=\dfrac{1}{(x+4)^2}
We multiply the formula for f(x) by \dfrac{1}{3}: ~~g(x)=\dfrac{1}{3}\sqrt[3]{x}
We make the formula for f(x) negative: ~~g(x)=-|x|

statement.p:
Write a formula for the transformed function.
f(x)=x^2-3x,~~g(x)=f(x+1)
f(x)=x^3+\sqrt{x},~~g(x)=-2f(x)
f(x)=5-\dfrac{2}{x},~~g(x)=f(x)-8
f(x)=\dfrac{4x-7}{x^2},~~g(x)=f(x-2)

ol.label: a
ol.li: We replace x by x+1 wherever it appears in the formula for f(x): ~~g(x)=(x+1)^2-3(x+1)
We multiply the formula for f(x) by -2: ~~g(x)=-2x^3-2\sqrt{x}
We subtract 8 from the formula for f(x): ~~g(x)=-3-\dfrac{2}{x}
We replace x by x-2 wherever it appears in the formula for f(x): ~~g(x) = \dfrac{4(x-2)-7}{(x-2)^2}

subsection.title: 2. Make a table for a transformed function

solution.p:
This transformation is a shift in the y-direction. We subtract 4 from each value of f(x).
x -2 -1 0 1 2
f(x) -8 -1 0 1 8
g(x) -12 -5 -4 -3 4

This transformation is a shift in the x-direction. It is helpful to insert another row into the table.
x -4 -2 0 2 4
x-4 -8 -6 -4 -2 0
f(x-4) 8 6 4 2 0
g(x) 8 6 4 2 0

subsection.title: 3. Identify the order of operations in a transformed function

introduction.p: First, identify the basic functions. Then follow the order of operations to describe the transformation.

statement.p: State the basic function and the transformations needed to graph ~~F(x)=5 \sqrt[3]{x}+6.

solution.p:
The basic function is ~f(x)=\sqrt[3]{x}~. The output is multiplied by 5, and then 6 is added, so the transformations are
~g(x)=5f(x)~, so the basic graph is stretched vertically by a factor of 5
and ~F(x)=g(x)+6~, so g(x) is shifted up by 6 units.

statement.p: State the basic function and the transformations needed to graph ~~G(x)=\dfrac{-3}{(x-1)^2}.

solution.p:
The basic function is ~f(x)=\dfrac{1}{x^2}~. We subtract 1 from the input, then multiply the output by -3, so the transformations are
~g(x)=f(x-1)~, so the basic graph is shifted 1 unit to the right
and ~G(x)=-3g(x)~, so g(x) is reflected about the x-axis and stretched vertically by a factor of 3.

statement.p: State the basic function and the transformations needed to graph ~~F(x)=\sqrt{x+6}+2

answer.p:
The basic function is ~f(x)=\sqrt{x}~. Then
~g(x)=f(x+6)~: shift 6 units left
~F(x)=g(x)+2~: shift 2 units up

statement.p: State the basic function and the transformations needed to graph ~~G(x)=\dfrac{1}{4}(x-3)^3

answer.p:
The basic function is ~f(x)=x^3~. Then
~g(x)=f(x-3)~: shift 3 units right
~F(x)=\dfrac{1}{4}g(x)~: compress vertically by a factor of 4
